awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation Award: Engineered demographic-specific in vitro microfluidic bone microenvironment models
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building a research program. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at his home institution, and involves undergraduate and high school students in research experiences. The award to Hampton University has potential broader and societal impact in a number of areas. The project focuses on transdisciplinary research in the area of bone tissue engineering to facilitate the optimization of treatment of complex bone diseases based on race-specific regimes.  These studies will build upon the current relationship between Hampton University and the Brandeis University Materials Research Science and Engineering Center through the recently established Partnership for Research and Education in Materials project.

This research project will apply the basic science and engineering techniques of biomaterials, cell culture, 3D printing, and microfluidics to fabricate race-specific microenvironment bone models. The objectives of this project are to: 1) determine the most informative 3D printing and microfluidic techniques that incorporate an engineered biomaterial to model bone homeostasis; 2) identify key cell/bone matrix interactions using an engineered bone microfluidic system as it relates to differences in bone homeostasis among various patient demographics; and 3) predict disturbances in bone homeostasis based on bone matrix differences between demographic groups with an engineered bone microfluidic system. The work is designed to be transformative on several levels: the methodology of human tissue integration to create race-specific in vitro systems, the advancement of solvent 3D printed microfluidic devices for biomedical applications, and the multidisciplinary approach designed to study the relationship between cells and extracellular matrices in a controlled environment. Expected outcomes would include the unique ability to ascertain key race-specific details about bone homeostasis in high throughput systems.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Impact:

The fabrication of biocompatible biocomposites is a challenge as challenges such as printability/process, homogeneity, and mechanical properties have to be addressed.  The successful implementation of such fabrication would allow for the development of patient-specific implants in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.    This work provided the foundations of several potential approaches for printing composite materials for tissue engineering.  Torque extrusion for polyurethane-based composites, and the filler percentage of bone particles (60 wt%–70 wt%) was shown to affect the adhesion of the materials to the printer platform (Figure 1).  Heated extrusion of polycaprolactone-based materials required careful temperature control to ensure shape integrity.  In collaboration with the University of Virginia, UV-curable polyurethane/hydrogel materials were explored for potential 3D-printing applications. 

 

Broader Impact: 

This funding was instrumental in the startup of the PI’s lab, the “Bioinspired Polymer Engineering Lab”, at an Historically Black College and University (HBCU) that included instrument acquisition, support for students, opportunities for professional development, and involvement in other NSF grants (PREM and I-Corps).  Three undergraduates are currently pursuing doctorates in STEM, while all other participants are in the STEM industry or are completing their STEM degrees.  This work included a total of nine HBCU undergraduates and four high school students (from the New Horizons Governor’s School for Science and Technology).  The various aspects of this work have been disseminated through oral presentations, posters presentations, panels, senior capstone projects and manuscripts.  This NSF-funded lab also served as a tour stop for prospective STEM undergraduate students.  Data from this work is has provided the foundation for future studies in multi-responsive materials.  

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2024
Modified by: Jerald Dumas

    Jerald Dumas
